sn1.34:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn1.34:4.2: Then, late at night, several beautiful gods of the Satullapa Group, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha,
sn1.34:4.3: bowed, and stood to one side.
sn1.34:4.4: Standing to one side, one deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn1.34:5.1: “Among humans there are no sensual pleasures that are permanent.
sn1.34:5.2: Here there are desirable things, bound to which,
sn1.34:5.3: drunk on which, there’s no coming back.
sn1.34:5.4: That person doesn’t return here from the realm of death.”
sn1.34:6.1: “Misery is born of desire; suffering is born of desire;
sn1.34:6.2: when desire is removed, misery is removed;
sn1.34:6.3: when misery is removed, suffering is removed.”
sn1.34:7.1: “The world’s pretty things aren’t sensual pleasures.
sn1.34:7.2: Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.
sn1.34:7.3: The world’s pretty things stay just as they are,
sn1.34:7.4: but a sage removes desire for them.
sn1.34:8.1: You should give up anger and get rid of conceit,
sn1.34:8.2: and get past all the fetters.
sn1.34:8.3: Sufferings don’t torment the one who has nothing,
sn1.34:8.4: not clinging to name and form.
sn1.34:9.2: craving for name and form is cut off right here.
sn1.34:9.3: They’ve cut the ties, untroubled and free of hope.
sn1.34:9.4: Though gods and humans search for them
sn1.34:9.5: both here and beyond, they never find them,
sn1.34:9.6: not in heaven nor in any abode.”
sn1.34:10.1: “If neither gods nor humans see one freed in this way
sn1.34:10.2: either here nor beyond,” said Venerable Mogharāja,
sn1.34:10.3: “are those who revere that best of men,
sn1.34:10.4: who lives for the good of mankind, also worthy of praise?”
sn1.34:11.1: “The mendicants who revere one freed in this way
sn1.34:11.2: are also worthy of praise, Mogharāja,” said the Buddha.
sn1.34:11.3: “But having understood the teaching and given up doubt,
sn1.34:11.4: those mendicants can get over clinging.”
